column9: AP is a rapid, transient change in the membrane potential of an excitable cell that propagates along the cell membrane due to the opening and closing of voltage-gated ion channels.
Propagation is the transmission of signals, waves, or disturbances through a medium or system.
Myelination is the process by which axons are insulated by a fatty myelin sheath, increasing the speed of nerve impulse conduction.
Saltatory conduction is the process by which action potentials jump between nodes of Ranvier along a myelinated axon, allowing faster electrical transmission than continuous conduction.
Demyelinating disorders are diseases in which the protective myelin sheath of nerve fibers is damaged, causing impaired nerve conduction.
Lectrochemical gradients are differences in electrical potential and chemical concentration across a membrane that drive the movement of ions and molecules.
Ionic movement is the motion of charged atoms or molecules (ions) through a medium such as an electrolyte or across a biological membrane.
Trivial case is an ordinary or unremarkable situation that does not require special attention.
Membrane potential is the electrical potential difference across a cell's membrane that results from uneven ion distribution and selective membrane permeability.
Atpase is an enzyme that hydrolyzes ATP to ADP and inorganic phosphate.
The S-P pump is a membrane protein that uses ATP to pump sodium ions out of cells and potassium ions into cells.
An Ion pump is a membrane protein that transports ions across a cell membrane, typically using energy to move them against their concentration gradient.
Depolarization is the process by which a cell's membrane potential becomes less negative, reducing the membrane's polarization.
Hyperpolarization is an increase in a cell membrane's electrical potential that makes the inside more negative relative to the outside.
Synapse is the junction between two nerve cells where electrical or chemical signals are transmitted across the gap.
Repolarization is the process by which a cell's membrane potential returns toward its resting negative value after depolarization.
A Chemical gradient is a difference in the concentration of a chemical substance between two regions, often across a membrane.
Intracellular describes something located or occurring inside a cell.
Concentration is the amount of a substance per unit volume or mass in a mixture or solution.
A phospholipid is a lipid molecule that contains a phosphate group and forms the basic structure of cell membranes.
A bilayer is a structure made of two layers.
Mammalian describes animals of the class Mammalia that are characterized by hair and mammary glands.

column1: Canonical ionic distributions - 典型离子分布
column9: Canonical ionic distributions describe the typical spatial arrangements of ions in a material or solution, indicating characteristic charge and concentration patterns.

column1: Graded (Passive) potentials - 分级（被动）电位
column9: Graded (Passive) potentials are changes in membrane potential whose amplitude varies with stimulus strength and that spread passively along the membrane without being regenerated by voltage-gated channels.
Threshold potential is the critical membrane voltage at which a neuron or muscle cell initiates an action potential.
Overshoot is the amount by which a system exceeds its target or steady-state value during a transient response.
Undershoot means a downward movement that briefly pushes a price or value below a target or support level.
Drift means to move slowly or be carried along by water, wind, or another force.

column1: V-G ion channels - 电压门控离子通道
column9: V-G ion channels are membrane proteins that open or close in response to changes in membrane voltage, allowing specific ions to pass across the cell membrane.
Gastropod is any member of the class Gastropoda, a group of mollusks that includes snails and slugs and is characterized by a single muscular foot used for locomotion.
Nodes of ranvier are periodic gaps in the myelin sheath along an axon where ion channels concentrate and saltatory conduction occurs.
Saltatory conduction is the rapid propagation of action potentials along myelinated axons in which impulses jump from one node of Ranvier to the next.
Pathologies refers to the branch of medicine that studies the causes, development, and effects of diseases.
Autoimmune describes a condition in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks its own tissues.
Multiple sclerosis is a chronic autoimmune disease of the central nervous system in which the myelin sheath of nerve fibers is damaged, causing a range of neurological symptoms.

column1: Guillain-barré syndrome - 格林－巴利综合征
column9: Guillain-barré syndrome is an acute autoimmune condition in which the immune system attacks peripheral nerves, causing rapid-onset muscle weakness and sometimes paralysis.
